title: These 10 Footballers Opted For Different Sports After Hanging Up Their Boots
text:
These 10 Footballers Opted For Different Sports After Hanging Up Their Boots

These 10 Footballers Opted For Different Sports After Hanging Up Their Boots

Sportspersons changing sport after hanging their boots is nothing new. In fact the world's favourite sport, football, has seen some of its big names opt for other sports after they gave up the beautiful game.

Givemesport

Here's a look at 10 such players who opted for other sports once they called it a day on the pitch. Let's find out who did what:

1. Paolo Maldini - tennis

His professional career lasted just 42 minutes as he lost 6-1, 6-1 while teaming up with Stefano Landonio in a match vs Tomasz Bednarek and David Pel at the Aspria Tennis Cup.

2. Bixente Lizarazu - jiu-jitsu

He first competed for a major title in 2009 and became European champion in the Blue Belt Senior 1 Light Division.

3. Rio Ferdinand - boxing

Sadly while he tried to be a professional boxer he could never become one end his professional career ended 0-0.

4. Curtis Woodhouse - boxing

24 wins in 31 fights is a good record. He is also a former British light-welterweight champion.

5. Michael Owen - horse-racing

He was a jockey for one race only and in 2017 finished second in a charity race.

6. Jerzy Dudek - motor racing

He competed in the 2014 Volkswagen Castrol Cup.

7. Tim Wiese - wrestling

He took part in WWE and teamed up with Sheamus and Cesaro to defeat The Shining Stars and Bo Dallas.

8. Gabriel Batistuta - polo

Scored twice on his debut for the Loro Piana polo club and won the Copa Stella Artois trophy as well.

9. Santiago Canizares - rally driving

In 2010 he competed in the Spanish Rally Championship and did so again in 2011. In 2016 he crashed his car in the Sierra Morena Rally but was unharmed. The 2017 Rally de la Ceramica was his first victory.

10. Petr Cech - ice hockey

Just after leaving football, he signed up for Guldford Phoenix and is playing for the second tier side in British ice hockey.
